Enhancing photocatalytic C-O/N coupling reaction over covalent organic frameworks by pull-push electron group regulation Ce Song Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft 1 Teng Yan Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft 1 Xiaoxia Cui Formal analysis Data curation Hao Chen Funding acquisition Supervision Ranfeng Ye Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Xiaohu Zhang Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ College of Science, Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan 430070, PR China College of Science, Huazhong Agricultural University Wuhan 430070 PR China College of Science, Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan 430070, P. R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have emerged as novel materials in photocatalytic technology for green energy and chemicals production. However, exploring highly efficient and stable COFs based materials for photocatalytic aromatic ethers and amines synthesis is still urgent. Herein, olefin-linked COFs modified with or without –F/-OCH3 groups were constructed by Knoevenagel condensation reaction. In addition, Ni active sites were embedded in the frameworks through bipyridine units to afford highly efficient and repeatable photocatalytic C-O/N coupling reaction. Through this strategy, it was found that the -F group modification greatly elevated photogenerated carriers separation efficiency attributing to its strong electronegativity and electron-withdrawing properties. Photocatalytic experiments conveyed that sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni displayed highest photocatalytic activity and catalyzed cross-coupling of aryl C-O/N both with high yield exceeding 99 %, and exhibited excellent substrate compatibility for aryl bromides substituted with electron-withdrawing/donating groups. This investigation provides new insights into structure design of COFs for photocatalytic organic transformation. Graphical Abstract Olefin-linked COFs modified with -F or -OCH3 groups are constructed, and the Ni active sites are embedded into the COF skeleton by bipyridine unit to realize highly efficient and repeatable photocatalytic C-O/N coupling reaction. ga1 Keywords Covalent organic frameworks Photocatalysis Pull-push electron group Organic transformation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aromatic ethers and amines are ubiquitous and important precursors in many natural products, active pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals [1–3]. Researchers have made great efforts to construct C-O/N bonds in aromatic ethers and amines. Traditional Pd- or Cu- catalyzed synthesis methods, such as Buchwald–Hartwig and Ullmann coupling reactions, need harsh reaction conditions and cause high toxicity by excessive use of heavy metal salts [4–7]. Thus, numerous researchers are exploring new sustainable methods. Recently, as a novel green and sustainable technology, semiconductor based photocatalysis has attracted worldwide attention in the field of organic transformation, solar energy conversion and pollutant treatment [8–12]. Under light irradiation, photosensitizers can be excitedand generate e-/h+ pairs or some highly reactive intermediates, which will participate in following redox reactions under mild conditions. Especially, photocatalytic organic transformations realized by photocatalysts provide a new idea to replace traditional organic synthesis [13–16]. In the procedure of photocatalysis, the physical and chemical properties of photocatalyst are very important. Although traditional Ir and Ru based homogeneous catalysts exhibit good catalytic reaction ability and substrate compatibility, they are limited by the difficulty of catalyst recovery and the shortcomings of precious metal nature [16–18]. Thus, series of heterogeneous catalysts, especially noble-metal-free catalysts, have been widely studied due to their advantages of repeatable utilization. In the past few decades, researchers have successfully constructed a variety of heterogeneous photocatalysts, such as inorganic semiconductors (TiO2, CdS and MOFs) and organic semiconductors including g-C3N4, conjugated microporous polymers [19–23]. However, there are still some problems, such as low visible light utilization efficiency, heavy metal toxicity, photocorrosion effects, which hinder the practical utilization of photocatalytic technology up till now [24]. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have been widely used in gas adsorption, separation, photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, sensing, supercapacitors, battery, pollutant degradation and other fields due to their large surface area, good thermochemical stability, long range ordered structure, easy adjustment of band gap width, and structural diversification [25–31]. Studies show that compared with traditional semiconductor photocatalysts such as TiO2 and g-C3N4, two-dimensional COFs have better photoelectric performance [32–35], and their highly ordered crystal structure shows unique photocatalytic potential [36–38]. Partially fluoridation of iminelinked two-dimensional triazine covalent organic framework (TF50-COF) photocatalyst is beneficial to adjust the electron distribution of adjacent carbon atoms and broaden the corresponding range of visible light of the catalyst [39]. In addition, the structural diversification of COFs allows researchers to embed nitrogen-containing functional groups such as bipyridine, porphyrin and phthalocyanine into the COFs backbone, which can be used as a catalytic active site for photo/electrocatalytic CO2 reduction and photocatalytic hydrogen production after chelating Ni or Co metal ions [40–46]. Yaghi et al. introduced different numbers of -F and -OCH3 groups into COFs to achieve the regulation of active site. Efficient charge transport along the backbone of COFs facilitates electronic communications between remote functional groups and active sites, thus enabled tuning of their catalytic performance [47]. Recently, some Ni-complexes and COFs have also been investigated in photocatalytic organic transformations. For example, Xue et al. reported the successful catalysis of C-O and C-N coupling reactions using NiII complexes as catalysts under blue light irradiation [48–50]. Similarly, Yang et al. found that NiIII-aryl complexes can act as photosensitizers and provide active sites, which can be used as homogeneous photocatalysts for C-O cross-coupling under 390–395 nm ultraviolet light irradiation, demonstrating the ability of Ni photocatalytic C-O coupling [51]. Recently Xiao et al. reported CdS as a photosensitizer combined with NiCl2·6 H2O to catalyze the C-O/N coupling reaction under blue light irradiation [52]. Similarly, g-C3N4 combined with Ni also successfully achieved this conversion [53]. In our previous work, for example, Xiang et al. synthesized a highly stable olefin linked sp2c-COFdpy-Ni involving 1,3,6,8-tetrakis(4-formylphenyl)pyrene (TFPPY) and 2,2′-([2,2′-bipyridine]−5,5′-diyl)- diacetonitrile (BPY-CN) via Knoevenagel condensation, which integrated photosensitizer and active site and exhibited excellent photocatalytic C-O performance [54]. However, the complete reaction time (20 h) for C-O coupling reactions still needs to be decreased through structual regulation. In addition, the influence of substituent groups on internal electron transfer and photocatalytic activities is of great important for design of COFs. Herein, typical electron push-pull groups such as -F/-OCH3 were introduced into the main chain of sp2c-COFdpy to synthesis sp2c-F-COFdpy and sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy, and then Ni sites were introduced into these COFs by post-modification ( Scheme 1). The photoactivities of sp2c-COFdpy-Ni, sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni, sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy-Ni for C-O/N coupling reactions were compared to explore the influence of electron push-pull groups, which displayed that sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni exhibited highest photogenerated charge separation efficiency and photoactivity for both C-O and C-N coupling reactions under blue light irradiation. 2 Results and discussion Three tetragonal lattice 2D COFs are synthesized by base-catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation reaction in which TFPPY/TFPPY-F/TFPPY-OCH3 and BPY-CN were used as precursors. Ni2+ was successfully introduced into COF structure with a molar ratio of bipyridine to NiCl2·6 H2O of 1 equiv. Ni fractions in sp2c-COFdpy-Ni, sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni, sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy-Ni were identified as 2.9 wt%, 3.1 wt% and 3.3 wt% respectively by Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS). Fig. 1(a) displays the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the synthesized COFs, in which the COFs have similar diffraction peaks and the patterns are consistent with Pawley refinement of eclipsed AA stacking model. In addition, fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) and solid-state 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy are both efficient characterization methods to demonstrate the successful preparation of COF materials. In FTIR spectra of the sp2c-COFdpy, sp2c-F-COFdpy, sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy (Fig. 1b), the peak around 2210 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration peak of CN in the local magnification. Compared with TFPPY, the aldehydic C-H (2720 and 2807 cm−1) and CO (1689 cm−1) of COFs material was significantly reduced, which proved that the preparation of COFs was successful. Other peaks at about 1800 cm−1 and 1200 cm−1 belong to skeleton peak of pyrene structure.[42,54] The formation of Schiff base linkage in sp2c-COFdpy, sp2c-F-COFdpy, sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy is confirmed by solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy (Fig. S1). The peaks at 122, 131 and 144 ppm correspond to carbon peaks in bipyridine of COF structures. The coordination states of Ni ions in sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Ni 2p of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni shows two peaks at 853.5 eV and 870.9 eV, corresponding to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 energy levels of Ni2+ [55,56]. Satellite peaks appeared at 860.2 eV and 879.8 eV, and other Ni species were not detected, as shown in Fig. 1(c). In Fig. S2, sp2c-COFdpy, sp2c-F-COFdpy, and sp2c-F-CoFdpy-Ni show nanofibers morphology with similar sizes. The difference is that the nanostructure of sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy has undergone significant changes, showing the agglomeration of nanoparticles. The photochemical properties of sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy-Ni were analyzed by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) and photoelectrochemical tests, etc., to explore the influence of introducing -F on the performance of C-O coupling reaction. As shown in Fig. 2(a), sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy-Ni exhibits good light absorption in the 400–800 nm band, with the highest absorption peak at around 460 nm, and the absorption band edge extended to 800 nm, the introduction of -F/-OCH3 had little effect on its light absorption capacity. In the Fig. 2(b, c), the introduction of -F leads to the smallest Nyquist plot radius of sp2c-F-COFdpy in the electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS), which proves that the introduction of -F improves the photogenerated carrier migration rate and is conducive to the migration of photogenerated electrons to the active site [57,58], thus further improving the photocatalytic C-O/N coupling reaction rate. In Fig. S3, sp2c-COFdpy, sp2c-F-COFdpy and sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy show similar patterns, which are consistent with the results of photocatalytic C-O coupling. The etherification of 4-bromobenzonitrile with CH3OH was selected as research object utilizing sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni as catalyst in Ni-redox mediated C-O cross-coupling reaction, and all of other reaction parameters (photocatalysts, base and solvents) were systematically optimized. As shown in Table 1, sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni has the best photocatalytic activity by screening experimental parameters. The target 4-methoxy-benzonitrile was obtained with yield of 99% in the presence of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni under irradiation with a 6 W LEDs lamp (λmax = 460–465 nm) (entry 1) within 13 h. The reaction failed to happen in the absence of light or base (entry 2 and 4), indicating that they were essential for the reaction. No products were detected during the reaction in an aerobic environment (entry 3). The type of alkali catalyst plays an important role in the reaction. No product was detected by substituting K2CO3 for DIPEA, and DIPEA was proven to be an excellent alkali catalyst. The catalytic yields of sp2c-COF-Ni and sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy-Ni substituted for sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni were 63 % and 9.8 %, respectively (entries 6 and 7). Entry 8 and 9 demonstrate the role of Ni and dipyridyl are necessary for C-O coupling, with bipyridine-Ni coordination acting as the main reaction site compared to biphenyls. Ni ion was selected as the active site through a series of solvent screening, mainly including CH3OH, DMF, acetonitrile, etc. The results showed that increasing solvent would lead to slower reaction speed (entries 10 and 11). Finally, ethanol and isopropyl alcohol were used instead of methanol for the reaction, and the product yields were 98 % and 30 % respectively (entry 12). After screening the optimal reaction conditions, in order to verify the practical application value of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni in photocatalytic aryl C-O coupling, the following substrate expansion experiment ( Scheme 2) was conducted. Under the same reaction conditions, using sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni as the model catalyst, the electron-withdrawing substituent-introduced bromobenzene derivatives exhibited better photocatalytic C-O coupling reaction efficiency, which may be attributed to the electron-withdrawing effect favoring the generation of de-brominated products of bromobenzene derivatives. When methanol is converted to ethanol, especially isopropyl alcohol, the reactivity is significantly reduced, which may be the result of steric hindrance. The Ni active site of sp2c-COFdpy-Ni is located in its own pore structure. The reaction process first requires the substrate to enter the pores of the catalyst to contact with Ni, and then go through the steps of oxidative addition and reductive elimination. However, the large steric hindrance of isopropanol limits its contact with active sites, which reduces the reaction rate. Using amination of 4-bromobenzonitrile with pyrrolidines as the model, sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni was introduced for Ni-redox mediated C-N cross coupling reaction. And other reaction parameters such as photocatalyst, base and solvents were screened experimentally. The reaction rates of three kinds of COFs-Ni were compared by control variable method, and sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni showed the best catalytic performance. As summarized in Table 2, the target 4-(1-pyrrolidine)benzonitrile is obtained in 99 % yield in the presence of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni under irradiation with a 18 W LEDs lamp (λmax = 460–465 nm) (entry 1). The reaction failed to happen in the dark of or in air (entry 2 and 3), indicating that both light and anaerobic environment were essential for the reaction. When N, N-diisopropylethylamine was added to the reaction system, the yield of the reaction was reduced, possibly due to the competitive reaction between the base and the substrate, which reduced the concentration of the substrate (entry 4). The sp2c-F-COFdpy instead of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni was used for the reaction, and no product was detected, indicating that Ni is indispensable in this reaction process (entry 5). Finally, the solvent test results show that the choice of solvent has a significant effect on the performance of the catalyst, DMAc system is better than acetonitrile, THF and DMF (entry 9, 10 and 11). Similarly, we also carried out the following substrate expansion experiment ( Scheme 3). In order to highlight the advantages of easy recovery and strong stability of our material compared to traditional homogeneous catalysts, the sp2c-COFdpy-Ni was recycled without any loss of the Ni-containing active sites by filtration and washing with methanol when the reaction was complete. The recovered sp2c-COFdpy-Ni exhibited comparable photocatalytic ability in the new reaction, and no apparent decrease in the yield was observed even after four repeated cycles without any extra supplement of Ni species. As shown in Fig. 3(a), sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni still had 96% yield after experiencing four cycles. In addition, FTIR and XPS showed that there were no obvious changes of the structure before and after photocatalytic C-O/N coupling, as shown in Fig. 3(b-d). The gram scale reaction was used to explore the practicability of C-O/N reactions. We increased the amount of p-bromobenzonitrile as a substrate by 20 times. The target product was obtained in 98% yield at 24 h and 48 h, respectively ( Scheme 4). In order to explore the potential mechanism of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni photocatalytic C-O coupling, Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was used to detect the active Ni species in sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni photocatalytic C-O coupling. By changing the reaction conditions (replacement of solvent, amount of substrate catalyst), the EPR signal of Ni was not detected, which may be attributed to the low content of Ni in sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni (Fig. S4). In our previous work, a mechanism was proposed for C-O coupling reaction with sp2c-COFdpy-Ni as catalyst: the strong interlayer electron transfer in COFs under blue light irradiation may facilitate the generation of intermediate sp2c-COFdpy-NiI in bimolecular and self-sustaining forms, which subsequently undergo NiI-NiIII cycles through oxidative addition, ligand exchange and reductive elimination [59]. On the basis of the above characterization, we speculated the photocatalytic C-O and C-N coupling mechanism of sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni under blue light irradiation. The non-covalent interaction between COFs layers enhanced the interlayer electron transfer, and the sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiII undergone bimolecular electron transfer to generate a molecule of sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiI and a molecule of sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiIII. [60] In this process, the introduction of -F polarized the interlayer electron cloud and enhanced the interlayer non-covalent interaction and the interlayer electron migration, which was beneficial to the generation of the intermediate sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiI, while this step was the rate-determining step in the reaction cycle process. In addition, the introduction of -F formed an embedded weak D-strong A structure, which promoted the transfer of photogenerated charges to the bipyridine Ni active site. Subsequently, sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiI and aryl bromides undergo oxidative addition to sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiIII, ligand exchange with CH3OH in the presence of DIPEA and removal of HBr. Finally, reduction and elimination happened to generate sp2c-F-COFdpy-NiI and the target product, as shown in Fig. 4. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully prepared three 2D COFs by introducing electron withdrawing and pushing groups into the skeleton via Knoevenagel condensation. COFs-Ni prepared by post-modification combining photosensitize and reactive site, exhibited excellent catalytic activity for light-driven C-O/N coupling from aryl bromide. As an alternative to the conventional homogeneous or semi-heterogeneous catalysts, this method is sustainable due to the full recovery and repeated use of COFs-Ni without any decrease in activity. This protocol also is compatible with substrates with different functional groups. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra and photoelectrochemical tests demonstrated that the introduction of -F enhanced the efficient migration of photogenerated electrons to the active sites and realized the regulation of active sites. As an emerging class of materials, we anticipate that 2D COFs will become a valuable type of environmentally friendly and sustainable photocatalyst for the traditional photoredox/ transition metal dual catalysis. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Synthesis of COFs Sp2c-COFdpy. 4,4',4'',4'''-(pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetrayl)tetrabenzaldehyde (TFPPY, 30.9 mg, 0.5 mmol), 2,2′-([2,2′-bipyridine]−5,5′-diyl)diacetonitrile (BPY-CN, 23.4 mg, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (1 mL) and KOH aqueous solution (0.1 mL, 4 M) were added to a 10 mL pyrex tube. The mixture was sonicated for 3 min, degassed by three freeze–pump–thaw cycles (liquid N2), sealed under vacuum and heated at 150 °C for three days. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with ultrapure water and THF successively until the filtrate was colorless. TFPPY-BPY-CN was afforded as the red powder after being dried at 60 °C under vacuum overnight. Sp2c-F-COFdpy. 4,4',4'',4'''-(pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetrayl)tetrakis(2-fluorobenzaldehyde) (TFPPY-F, 34.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), 2,2′-([2,2′-bipyridine]−5,5′-diyl)diacetonitrile (BPY-CN, 23.4 mg, 1.0 mmol), n-BuOH (0.75 mL), o-DCB (0.25 mL) and DBU (0.1 mL) were added to a 10 mL pyrex tube. The mixture was sonicated for 3 min, degassed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles (liquid N2), sealed under vacuum and heated at 150 °C for three days. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with ultrapure water, THF and CH3OH successively until the filtrate was colorless. The final product sp2c-F-COFdpy was afforded as the red powder after being dried at 60 °C under vacuum overnight. Sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy. To a 10 mL pyrex tube, 4,4′,4′',4′''-(pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetrayl) tetrakis(2-methoxybenzaldehyde) (TFPPY-OCH3, 36.9 mg, 0.5 mmol), 2,2′-([2,2′-bipyridine]−5,5′-diyl)diacetonitrile (BPY-CN, 23.4 mg, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (0.5 mL), Mesitylene (0.5 mL) and DBU (0.1 mL) were added. The mixture was sonicated for 3 min, degassed by three freeze–pump–thaw cycles (liquid N2), sealed under vacuum and heated at 150 °C for three days. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with ultrapure water, THF and CH3OH successively until the filtrate was colorless. The final product sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy was afforded as the red powder after being dried at 60 °C under vacuum overnight. 4.2 Synthesis of COFs-Ni The suspension of COFs (sp2c-COFdpy/sp2c-F-COFdpy/sp2c-OCH3-COFdpy) (0.2 mmol theoretical bounding site) was treated with NiCl2·6 H2O (0.2 mmol), and the corresponding suspension in CH3OH (50 mL) was refluxed overnight under N2 protection, and the cooled precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with CH3OH thoroughly for removal of unbound metal salts, followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum overnight. coredata.dc:description: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have emerged as novel materials in photocatalytic technology for green energy and chemicals production. However, exploring highly efficient and stable COFs based materials for photocatalytic aromatic ethers and amines synthesis is still urgent. Herein, olefin-linked COFs modified with or without –F/-OCH3 groups were constructed by Knoevenagel condensation reaction. In addition, Ni active sites were embedded in the frameworks through bipyridine units to afford highly efficient and repeatable photocatalytic C-O/N coupling reaction. Through this strategy, it was found that the -F group modification greatly elevated photogenerated carriers separation efficiency attributing to its strong electronegativity and electron-withdrawing properties. Photocatalytic experiments conveyed that sp2c-F-COFdpy-Ni displayed highest photocatalytic activity and catalyzed cross-coupling of aryl C-O/N both with high yield exceeding 99 %, and exhibited excellent substrate compatibility for aryl bromides substituted with electron-withdrawing/donating groups. This investigation provides new insights into structure design of COFs for photocatalytic organic transformation.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing photocatalytic C-O/N coupling reaction over covalent organic frameworks by pull-push electron group regulation
